mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 7335569 APPLICATION YJCAT 12760 S0021-9517(18)30119-2 10.1016/j.jcat.2018.03.018 Elsevier Inc. Fig. 1 FESEM images of (a) MoS2; (b) MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s; (c) MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s; and (d) MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s. Fig. 2 High- and (inset) low-magnification TEM images of (a) MoS2; and (b) MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s. Fig. 3 Raman spectra within the range of 350–450 cm−1 for the MoS2 and O2-plasma treated MoS2 samples. The intensity ratios of the A1g mode to E2g 1 mode for all the MoS2 samples are shown in the figure. Fig. 4 (a) Raman spectra within the range of 100–1100 cm−1 for the MoS2 and O2-plasma treated MoS2 samples. (b) XRD patterns of the O2-plasma treated MoS2 samples, together with the standard pattern of 2H MoS2 (JCPDS 75-1539). Fig. 5 High resolution of XPS (a) O 1s and (b) Mo 3d spectra for MoS2 and O2-plasma treated MoS2 samples. Fig. 6 (a) Polarization curves of the commercial MoS2 and O2 plasma treated MoS2 catalysts in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution at a scan rate of 5 mV/s. (b) Charging current density differences plotted against scan rate of the O2 plasma treated MoS2 catalysts, Cdl is equivalent to the slope of the fitted line. (c) Tafel plots for the O2 plasma treated MoS2 catalysts derived from (a). (d) Nyquist plots of the O2 plasma treated MoS2 catalysts at the overpotential of 200 mV and the corresponding equivalent circuit that fits the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data. Fig. 7 Polarization curves recorded from the (a) MoS2, (b) MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s, (c) MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s, and (d) MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts at a scan rate of 5 mV/s before and after the chronopotentiometry test. Inset: chronopotentiometry responses (η ∼ t) recorded at a constant current density of −10 mA/cm2. Fig. 8 High resolution of XPS Mo 3d spectra for (a) MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and (b) MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts before and after the chronopotentiometry test at −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h. Fig. 9 FESEM images of (a) MoS2; (b) MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s; (c) MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s; and (d) MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts after the chronopotentiometry test at −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h. Fig. 10 (a) TEM image of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s sample after the chronopotentiometry test at −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h. (b) Raman spectra of the O2-plasma treated MoS2 samples after the chronopotentiometry test at −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h. The intensity ratios of the A1g mode to E2g 1 mode for all the MoS2 samples are shown in the figure. Janus effect of O2 plasma modification on the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction of MoS2 Chengxu Zhang a Lin Jiang b Yingjie Zhang a Jue Hu b ⁎ Michael K.H. Leung c d ⁎ a The Engineering Laboratory of Advanced Battery and Materials of Yunnan Province, Faculty of Metallurgical and Energy Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China The Engineering Laboratory of Advanced Battery and Materials of Yunnan Province Faculty of Metallurgical and Energy Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming China b Faculty of Science, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China Faculty of Science Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming China c Ability R&D Energy Research Centre, School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China Ability R&D Energy Research Centre School of Energy and Environment City University of Hong Kong Hong Kong, China d The City University of Hong Kong Shenzhen Research Institute, Shenzhen, China The City University of Hong Kong Shenzhen Research Institute Shenzhen China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Faculty of Science, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, China (J. Hu); Ability R&D Energy Research Centre, School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China (M.K.H. Leung). Faculty of Science Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming China Graphical abstract Oxygen incorporation is a promising and effective way for simultaneously engineering the edge and planar sites of MoS2 to fabricate high-performance HER electrocatalysts. However, the insulating MoO3 species are inevitably generated during the oxygen incorporation process. Here, controlled plasma exposure time has been designed to explore the influence of MoO3 species on the HER performance for the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. We find that the MoO3 species in MoS2 are not conductive to the HER electrocatalysis. More importantly, the Raman spectrum, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, energy-disperse X-ray spectrum and transmission electron microscope analyses demonstrate that these co-generated MoO3 species are reduced and resolved from the MoS2 lattice during the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution, leading to a holey structure in the MoS2 nanosheets and thus a significant improvement of its hydrogen evolution stability. This work not only helps to understand the electrocatalytic influence of the co-generated MoO3 species in MoS2, but also presents a methodological improvement in designing defect-rich, oxygen incorporated and holey MoS2 nanosheets for highly efficient hydrogen evolution. Keywords Hydrogen evolution reaction MoS2 Oxygen incorporation MoO3 species Janus effect Plasma modification 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2), with the highest gravimetric energy density among the currently wildly used fuels and zero carbon content leading water as the sole product from its oxidation reaction, has been recognized as the most ideal and clean energy carrier to resolve the growing concern about energy crisis, environmental pollution and global warming, and fulfill our need for the future fuel applications [1–4]. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is the cathodic half reaction of electrocatalytic water splitting and is thus highly desirable to power the “hydrogen-based economy”. In electrolysis, noble metals, e.g. platinum (Pt) is still the best catalysts for the HER due to their high electrocatalytic activity. However, the widespread applications of Pt-based noble metal catalysts are hindered by their high cost, scarcity and insufficient stability [5,6]. Therefore, central to the electrocatalysis are efficient and robust electrocatalysts based on nonprecious metals, which are urgently needed for satisfying the hydrogen-based industry. Earth-abundant MoS2 has emerged as a promising HER catalyst with high electrocatalytic activity and stability due to its unique physical and chemical properties [7–9]. In the electronic structure of MoS2, the orbitals of HOMO states are mainly localized at the edged S sites, so that the localized electrons are mainly at the edge of MoS2 for charge exchange of proton [10]. DFT calculations have elucidated that the MoS2 plane sites are HER-catalytically inert with the hydrogen adsorption energy (ΔG H) of is ∼1.9 eV, while edge sites especially the [1 0 1 0] Mo edges are HER-catalytically active with a near-optimal ΔG H as ∼0.08 eV, which is even closer to 0 eV than that of the state-of-the-art Pt surfaces (ΔG H is ∼−0.1 eV) [11]. Inspired by this understanding, great efforts have been devoted to developing high-performance MoS2 nanostructures. On one hand, noteworthy MoS2 nanostructures including nanoparticle [12], nanosheet [13], amorphous MoS2 [14], film with ordered double-gyroid network [15], defect-rich nanosheet [16], and vertically aligned stepped edge terminated MoS2 sheet arrays [10] have been developed to maximizing the active edge sites and illustrated to have enhanced HER performance. On the other hand, optimizing the hydrogen adsorption on the inert planar sites by converting the 2H phase to the 1 T phase of MoS2 layers [17–19], distorting the MoS2 plane and introducing S-vacancy in the MoS2 planar sites [20] significantly facilitates the hydrogen binding and thus increases the HER activity. Therefore, simultaneous optimization of both the edge and planar sites of MoS2 materials is of great importance to fabricate the high-performance HER electrocatalyst. Xie and co-workers have recently reported a novel oxygen-incorporated MoS2 ultrathin nanosheet system, in which the oxygen incorporation could effectively reduce the bandgap, increase the intrinsic conductivity of MoS2 catalyst, and thus enhance its HER performance [21]. In addition, it was believed that such enhancement of HER performance for O-incorporated MoS2 catalyst could be attributed to not only the enhanced intrinsic conductivity and expanded interlayer spaces, but also the modulated hydrogen binding free energy on the inert planar sites [21–24]. More recently, O2 plasma was used to engineer the defect-rich and oxygen incorporated structure of MoS2 to enhance its electrocatalytic activity for HER [25]. Plasma modification is a mild and efficient way to introduce disordered structure and functional foreign atoms on the materials’ surface [26–31]. It is believed that there are a variety of reactive species (e.g. electrons, ions and neutral radicals, etc.) generated during the plasma discharge [32,33]. The high-energy electrons in O2 plasma contribute to the plasma bombardment and ablation, leading to the cracking of the basal planes of MoS2 and thus defect-rich edge structure. At the same time, the O-species (oxygen ions and oxygen radicals) in O2 plasma would incorporate into the MoS2 lattice due to their highly oxidative activity [34]. However, the generation of MoO3 species is found to be inevitable during the O2 plasma treatment or other O-incorporation processes [23,25,35]. The influence of these insulating MoO3 species on the HER activity and stability of MoS2 and its structure changes after long-term electrocatalytic reaction, which are significant to understand the HER electrocatalysis on the O-incorporated MoS2 catalysts, however, are still unknown. Herein, we used the one-step O2 plasma modification to simultaneously engineer the edge and planar structure of MoS2 to fabricate the high-performance MoS2 electrocatalyst with defect-rich edge and oxygen-doped planar structure. As expected, the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts possess a smaller HER onset potential and Tafel slope than that of the non-treated MoS2 catalyst, as well as the excellent long-term durability. To investigate the influence of MoO3 species on the HER performance, chemical structure and HER performance of the O2-plasma modified MoS2 catalysts before and after the long-term durability test were carefully analyzed. 2 Results and discussion We fabricated the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts via a two-step process. The MoS2 spheres were firstly synthesized by hydrothermal reaction, and then modified by O2 plasma with different plasma treatment time of 30 s (MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s), 60 s (MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s) and 120 s (MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s). The morphology of the as-synthesized MoS2 and O2 plasma treated MoS2 catalysts was characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) shown in Fig. 1 . The FESEM images clearly reveal the great difference among various MoS2 samples. Fig. 1a indicates that the hydrothermal synthesized 3D MoS2 microsphere is built from large quantities of uniform nanosheets with the edge length of 300–600 nm. Obviously, smaller edge length of the MoS2 nanosheets can be observed from Fig. 1b–d of the O2 plasma treated MoS2 samples, indicating more cracks in the MoS2 nanosheets comparing to the non-treated MoS2, and thus more exposed active edge sites on the O2 plasma treated MoS2 surface. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imageshave confirmed the ultrathin nanosheet morphology ofas-grown MoS2 samples. It can be clearly seen from the TEM image in Fig. 2 a that the MoS2 nanosheets were connected to each other through the center to form the 3D microsphere structure. As shown in the high-magnification TEM images, the MoS2 nanosheets exhibit an interlayer separation of 0.63 nm for both the MoS2 and MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s samples, corresponding to the (0 0 2) facet of 2H-MoS2 crystal (also see the XRD analysis below). Careful investigation of the TEM image reveals that the crystal fringes along the edge of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s sample are dislocated and discontinuous (indexed in Fig. 2b), suggesting a defect-rich structure for the plasma treated MoS2. The dislocated atomic arrangement causes the cracking of the basal planes and thus results in the formation of additional edges [16]. In addition, the corresponding Raman spectra as shown in Fig. 3 for all the MoS2 samples exhibited two distinct peaks at ∼405 cm−1 referred to the out-of-plane Mo-S phonon mode (A1g) and at ∼379 cm−1 corresponded to the in-plane Mo-S phonon mode (E2g 1) of typical MoS2 layer structure [36]. The relatively high intensity of the A1g mode for the O2 plasma modified MoS2 samples confirms more edge-terminated sites generated during plasma treatment process, which is in consistent with the SEM and TEM observations [37]. The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum of the as-grown MoS2 (see Fig. S1) reveals that the ratio of S to Mo is close to 2, confirming the successful synthesis of MoS2. It is worth noting that after the O2 plasma modification, O content in MoS2 samples becomes larger over the plasma processing time (Figs. S2–4), indicating that O2 plasma modification is an effective way to introduce oxygen species onto the MoS2 surfaces. To characterize those oxygen species, Raman spectra with large range were recorded for all the MoS2 samples, shown in Fig. 4 a. The spectra of all the MoS2 samples display two strong vibrational bands at ∼379 cm−1 and ∼405 cm−1, which are attributed to the Mo-S phonon mode of MoS2. Clearly, the Raman spectra of the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s and non-treated MoS2 samples are similar, indicating the similar chemical structure between them. However, there are three newly developed bands at 666 cm−1, 820 cm−1 and 995 cm−1 for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s, not present for MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s sample, which are responsible for the layered structure of the α-phase MoO3. The crystal structure of α-phase MoO3 contains three nonequivalent oxygen atoms in the MoO6 octahedral unit, which are edge sharing triply coordinated oxygen (O–Mo3), doubly coordinated oxygen (MoOMo), and terminal oxygen (MoO). The stretching mode for these three oxygen is located at 666 cm−1 for OMo3, 820 cm−1 for MoOMo and 995 cm−1 for MoO with the relative intensity ratio of 0.2:1:0.5 [38]. Nevertheless, the Raman spectra analysis indicates the formation of MoO3 species in the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s samples. Moreover, the intensity of these three bands dramatically increased when increasing the plasma processing time from 60 s to 120 s, indicating that much more surface MoO3 species formed. The chemical structure of MoS2 and O2 plasma modified MoS2 samples are further studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 4b, the XRD peaks observed at 2θ = 14.1°, 32.9°, 39.5° and 58.8° of all the MoS2 samples can be indexed to (0 0 2), (1 0 0), (1 0 3) and (1 1 0) facets of 2H-MoS2 crystal, respectively (JCPDS No. 75-1539, JCPDS = Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards). In agreement with the Raman analysis, the XRD patterns further evidence the present of α-phase MoO3 (marked using star in Fig. 4b) in the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s samples, not present for MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s sample, which show peaks at 2θ = 12.7° and 27.3° indexed to (0 2 0) and (0 2 1) facets of the α-phase MoO3, respectively (JCPDS No. 05-0508). The high-resolution TEM image in Fig. S5 of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s sample exhibits an interlayer separation of 0.35 nm, corresponding to the (0 4 0) facet of MoO3 crystal and the lattice fringes of 0.23 nm and 0.28 nm, which are agree well with the (1 0 3) and (1 0 0) lattice spacing of the 2H-MoS2 crystal, respectively. In consistent with the Raman and XRD results, the TEM image shows the direct evidence for the generation of the MoO3 in the O2 plasma modified MoS2 matrix. The asymmetric XPS O 1s spectrum of the as-grown MoS2 (Figs. 5 a and S6) can be divided into four distinct peaks: peak O1 at 530.1 eV corresponded to metal–oxygen bonds; peak O2 at 531 eV attributed to oxygen in OH− groups; peak O3 at 532.1 eV assigned to oxygen component with a higher number of defect sites but low oxygen coordination; and peak O4 at 533.1 eV referred to multiplicity of physi- and chemi-sorbed water at the surface [6,39]. In comparison, the O 1s spectra for the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s samples show a significant increase of a peak at 530.2 eV attributed to metal-oxygen bonds, verifying the successful O incorporation in the MoS2 lattice [21]. The Mo 3d spectrum of the as-synthesized MoS2 shows strong spin-orbit doublet peaks at 229.0 eV and 232.1 eV assigned to Mo4+ 3d5/2 and Mo4+ 3d3/2, respectively. The doublet peaks at 232.7 eV and 235.8 eV which are related to Mo6+ suggest a small amount of MoO3 species exist on the as-synthesized MoS2 surface, as shown in Fig. 5b [10]. After the plasma modification, the intensity of this doublet peaks significantly increased, confirming additional surface MoO3 species for the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s samples. Moreover, the XPS analyses also prove that the formation of the surface MoO3 species via O2 plasma treatment are highly relevant to the plasma processing time, which is in good consistent with the Raman and XRD results. Electrocatalytic performance of various MoS2 samples were investigated in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution using a three-electrode setup with the same loading of 3 mg/cm2 on carbon fiber paper substrate. During the electrochemical measurement, high-purity H2 is continuously purged into the electrolyte to saturate the electrolyte and fix the reversible hydrogen potential. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the O2 plasma modified MoS2 samples give a relatively low overpotential to the non-treated MoS2 at 10 mA/cm2. Among them, the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst exhibits a further boosted HER activity with the overpotential as low as 131 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2. It can be clearly seen that there is a redox peak at around −0.16 V vs. RHE for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts, which is ascribed to the insertion of hydrogen ions into the α-phase MoO3 lattice during the cathodic potential scan and then forming the MoO3-x with lower state of Mo [40]. Electrochemical double layer capacitances (Cdl), which is known to be proportional to the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) has been derived from the cyclic voltammetry curves in the potential range of 0.1–0.2 V vs. RHE with different scan rate in the potential range where no faradic current was observed (Fig. 6b) [41]. The halves of the positive and negative current density differences at the center of the scanning potential range (Δj 0.15V/2) are plotted versus the scan rate shown in Fig. S7. The Cdl of the O2-plasma modified MoS2 catalysts become larger than that of the non-treated MoS2 due to the newly generated active sites during plasma bombardment. It can be clearly found that the Cdl of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s (95 mF/cm2) is higher than that of the non-treated MoS2 (52 mF/cm2), MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s (60 mF/cm2) and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s (77 mF/cm2) catalysts, indicating a much higher electrochemical surface area of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst, and thus the superior HER activity. The ECSA normalized HER performance, as shown in Fig. S8, was analyzed to investigate a surface area corrected improvement of HER kinetics for these O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. Among them, the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s catalyst exhibits a highest ECSA normalized HER electrocatalytic activity, indicating that the MoO3 species in MoS2 is not conductive to the HER electrocatalysis. As shown in Fig. 6c, the Tafel slopes of MoS2, MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s, MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts were determined to be 83, 69, 74 and 77 mV/dec, respectively. Tafel analysis has been used to distinguish between different mechanistic pathways. The Tafel slopes of all the MoS2 catalysts are within the range of 39–116 mV/dec, indicate that the charge transfer steps govern the HER kinetics, where the Volmer step and Heyrovsky step become kinetically comparable [42]. The lower Tafel slope value of O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts than that of non-treated MoS2 indicates a superior HER kinetics. This was confirmed by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) as shown in Fig. 6d. The Nyquist plots at the overpotential of 200 mV show that the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst has the smallest charge transfer resistance (Rct) of only 3.3 Ω, indicating the ultrafast Faradaic process and thus a superior HER kinetics. The slightly higher Rs (serial resistance) of the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts may be due to the new generated cracking in the MoS2 layers and insulating MoO3 species. The electrocatalytic performances including the overpotential, Tafel slope, Cdl and charge transfer resistance of all the O2 plasma modified MoS2 samples were summarized in Table S1. Based on the morphology and chemical structure analyses, O2 plasma modification can effectively introduce additional active edge sites on the MoS2 nanostructure and incorporate O into the MoS2 lattice, both of which are benefit for the hydrogen evolution catalysis. After short time O2 plasma modification, the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s catalyst possesses more active edge sites in the MoS2 lattice, and thus exhibits superior HER activity than the as-grown MoS2 catalyst. Besides the defect-rich edge structure, there is confirmed structural evidence showing the successful O incorporation into the MoS2 lattice for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst. However, it is obvious that too much MoO3 species were introduced on the MoS2 surface when further extending the plasma exposure time to 120 s based on the Raman, EDS and XPS analyses, indicating a Janus effect of O-incorporation on HER properties of MoS2. The inferior HER activity of the MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalyst than MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s suggests that MoO3 species in MoS2 is not conductive to the HER electrocatalysis. Therefore, the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst, which possesses the highest degree of defects and moderate degree of O incorporation exhibits the highest HER activity among these four MoS2 catalysts. Long-term stability of MoS2 was assayed by mean of chronopotentiometry measurement (η ∼ t). The process was performed at a constant current density of −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h for all the MoS2 catalysts. From the inset pictures of Fig. 7 , it is clear that all the MoS2 catalysts show accepted stability with less than 10 mV increase of the overpotential after biased galvanostatically at −10 mA/cm2 for 20 h. In addition, after the chronopotentiometry measurement, the polarization curves of the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts show smaller negative shift from the initial one than that of the non-treated MoS2 catalyst, indicating an improvement of the HER stability. The redox peak at around −0.16 V vs. RHE for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts disappeared after the chronopotentiometry test, indicating the reduction of MoO3 species because of the electrochemical reduction characteristics during HER. It is worth noting from Fig. 7c that the cathodic overpotential required to maintain the current density of −10 mA/cm2 for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst decrease about 15 mv. Moreover, there is no negative shift of the polarization curve after the chronopotentiometry measurement relative to the initial one, further manifesting the striking long-term durability of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst on HER. In order to better compare the HER kinetics with the recently reported highly active MoS2-based catalysts, the overpotentials required for maintaining the HER current density of −10 mA/cm2 of most active MoS2-based catalysts were listed, as shown in Table S2. the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst exhibits a boosted HER activity with the overpotential as low as 131 mV at the current density of 10 mA/cm2 and striking long-term durability, better than most reported MoS2-based catalysts. SEM, TEM, EDS, XPS and Raman analyses were carried out on MoS2 catalysts to investigate the chemical structural and morphological changes of the those electrocatalysts after the long-term durability measurement, as shown in Figs. 8, 9 and S8–11. The Raman spectrum of the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s catalyst after electrochemical testing essentially the same as that of the initial one (Fig. S9), suggesting no obvious structural changes of the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s catalyst during the HER catalysis. However, it is obvious that the intensity of stretching mode for MoO3 components in the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts decreased, indicating the decrease of MoO3 species in MoS2. Further studying the SEM-EDS elementary analysis in Figs. S10–12, we can find that the O content in all the O2 plasma modified MoS2 samples, especially MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s, significantly decreased and the S/Mo ratio became close to 2:1 after the electrochemical testing, demonstrating the decrease of the MoO3 species in MoS2 during the long-term chronopotentiometry test, which is well consistent with the electrochemical analysis. The XPS spectra of the Mo 3d region for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts after the chronopotentiometry test are shown in Fig. 8. The intensity of the doublet peaks at 232.7 eV and 235.8 eV which are related to Mo6+ 3d5/2 and Mo4+ 3d3/2, respectively, markedly decreased. Accordingly, there are increased doublet peaks at 229 eV and 232.1 eV related to Mo4+, and doublet peaks at 230.0 eV and 233.4 eV attributed to MoO3-x, confirming the electro-reduction of the Mo6+ species during the hydrogen evolution catalysis [10,43]. The doublet peaks at 230.0 eV and 233.4 eV for MoO3-x can be seen in Fig. 9 for both the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalysts, verifying still an amount of incorporated O retained in the MoS2 lattice even after long-term durability test. Fig. 9 presents the SEM images of all the MoS2 samples, when comparing with the SEM images before chronopotentiometry test we can see that: (i) there is no difference in the morphology of the non-treated MoS2 catalyst after 20 h at −10 mA/cm2; (ii) the layered MoS2 morphology with basal planes cracked structure of the MoS2 O2-plasma 30 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s samples were highly preserved after the long-term durability test; and (iii) there is a significant difference in the morphology between the MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s catalyst before and after the long-term durability measurement due to the reduction and resolution of large amount of MoO3 species. Interestingly, the TEM images of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s sample after the durability test shown in Fig. 10 , display a holey structure of the MoS2 nanosheet. This holey structure of the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s sample which is attributed to the reduction and resolution of MoO3 species in MoS2 lattice can provide more additional active edge sites in the MoS2 nanostructure [44]. From the Raman spectra shown in Fig. 10b, the relatively high intensity ratios of the A1g mode to E2g 1 mode for MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s and MoS2 O2-plasma 120 s samples after the durability test confirms more edge-terminated sites generated after MoO3 species reduction and resolution, which is in consistent with the TEM observations. The increase of the active edge sites during the long-term HER process may result the significant improvement of the hydrogen evolution stability for the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. 3 Conclusion By engineering the defects and O-incorporation in the nanostructure of MoS2 through O2 plasma modification, the HER electrocatalytic activities including the electrochemical surface area, current density, onset potential, Tafel slope and charge transfer resistance can be improved effectively. Controlled plasma exposure time has been designed to explore the influence of MoO3 species on the HER performance of O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. We found that the degree of O-incorporation as well as the amount of MoO3 species increases with extending the plasma exposure time. MoO3 species in MoS2 is not conductive to the HER electrocatalysis. Therefore, the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst, which possesses the highest degree of defects and moderate degree of O incorporation exhibits the highest HER activity among the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. Moreover, the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst exhibits unfading catalytic performance after 20 h chronopotentiometry testing, manifesting the striking long-term durability on HER. More importantly, the MoS2 O2-plasma 60 s catalyst shows a holey structure after the long-term durability test due to the electro-reduction and resolution of the MoO3 species from MoS2 lattice, which provides more additional active edge sites in the MoS2 nanostructure, and thus, high HER activity and stability. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen incorporation is a promising and effective way for simultaneously engineering the edge and planar sites of MoS2 to fabricate high-performance HER electrocatalysts. However, the insulating MoO3 species are inevitably generated during the oxygen incorporation process. Here, controlled plasma exposure time has been designed to explore the influence of MoO3 species on the HER performance for the O2 plasma modified MoS2 catalysts. We find that the MoO3 species in MoS2 are not conductive to the HER electrocatalysis. More importantly, the Raman spectrum, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, energy-disperse X-ray spectrum and transmission electron microscope analyses demonstrate that these co-generated MoO3 species are reduced and resolved from the MoS2 lattice during the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution, leading to a holey structure in the MoS2 nanosheets and thus a significant improvement of its hydrogen evolution stability. This work not only helps to understand the electrocatalytic influence of the co-generated MoO3 species in MoS2, but also presents a methodological improvement in designing defect-rich, oxygen incorporated and holey MoS2 nanosheets for highly efficient hydrogen evolution.
coredata.dc:title: Janus effect of O2 plasma modification on the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction of MoS2
